listening.general: Can identify sounds of familiar words and basic phrases spoken slowly and clearly.
specific: Receptive: Recognize familiar words and basic phrases.
Interactive: Respond to simple conversations on familiar topics by using gestures or by pointing.
learning_outcomes: Can recognize familiar words related to days of the week spoken slowly (e.g., "Monday." "Today is Monday." "It's Monday.").
Can respond to the basic days of the week and weekend by pointing at the word or position on a basic calendar.
Can recognize and respond to questions about the days of the week using basic phrases (e.g., "Is today Tuesday?" "No, it is Saturday." "It is the weekend.").

speaking.general: Can use basic language and formulaic expressions to describe things and answer questions.
specific: Productive: Use basic words or phrases to identify time words.
Interactive: Exchange simple questions and answers about the current day.
learning_outcomes: Can identify specific time-related words, such as days of the week and the weekend, in simple sentences (e.g., "Saturday and Sunday are the weekends." "Today is Tuesday.").
Can exchange simple questions and answers about the current day, using basic time-related words (e.g., "What day is it today?" "Today is Monday.").
Can respond to questions about time using basic words and phrases to indicate days (e.g., "What is tomorrow?" "Tomorrow is Wednesday." or "It's the weekend.").

reading.general: Can recognize familiar words in simple texts.
specific: Reading: Find familiar words in a text.
Reading: Identify one-step written directions with visual support.
Phonemic Awareness: Identify sounds of the letters of the alphabet when supported with a concrete item or picture representing that sound.
learning_outcomes: Can find and point to familiar words in simple texts (e.g., "Monday," "Tuesday").

Can identify and follow one-step written directions with visual support (e.g., following the instruction, "Point to the word 'Monday'" in the sentence "Today is Monday," supported by a calendar picture).

Can identify the sounds of the letters of the alphabet in familiar vocabulary related to days of the week and daily routines when supported with a concrete item or picture representing that sound (e.g., identifying the sound /w/ in "Wednesday" supported with a picture).

writing.general: Can write about oneself using simple words.
specific: Productive: Write their own name and other very familiar words without assistance.
Interactive: Draw pictures related to a simple sentence they have written.
learning_outcomes: Can write their name and days of the week without assistance (e.g., "Yamileth" and "Tuesday").
Can write simple greetings on cards (e.g., "Happy Monday!").
Can draw pictures for sentences they have written (e.g., a greeting card for the sentence "Happy Monday!").

mediation.general: Can use mediation strategies such as gestures and body language to express basic ideas.
specific: Text: Use pictures or objects to express ideas.
Concept: Use facial expressions and simple gestures to help explain feelings or needs.
learning_outcomes: Can use simple drawings or pictures to communicate days of the week to peers (e.g., drawing a picture of a calendar showing the days of the week).
Can use gestures and facial expressions to express basic ideas about days of the week to others (e.g., pointing to a picture representing a specific day).
Can clarify misunderstandings about days of the week using body language (e.g., pointing to the correct day on a calendar).

vocabulary: Nouns: Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday, Friday, Saturday, Sunday, weekend, day, week

Adverbs of time: today, tomorrow
Numbers: 1-20
Adjectives: relaxing, exciting, busy, quiet
Prepositions of time: on, before, after
pronunciation_phonemic_awareness: Phonemic awareness: Recognizing sounds of letters of the alphabet in familiar words related to days of the week and routines

pragmatic: Exchanging questions and answers: Exchanging questions and answers about the current day using simple phrases like "Today is Monday."
Using time-related vocabulary: Identifying words for days and weekends by using or pointing to them
sociolinguistic: Classroom schedules: Using polite expressions when talking about the days of the week and routines.

listening.general: Can identify sounds of familiar words and basic phrases spoken slowly and clearly.
specific: Receptive: Follow very simple directions and instructions.
Interactive: Respond to simple conversations on familiar topics by using gestures or by pointing.
learning_outcomes: Can follow basic instructions related to weather (e.g., "Look outside, it's sunny.").
Can recognize weather-related words like "sunny" or "raining" in conversations.
Can respond to questions about the weather (e.g., "What is the weather today?").

speaking.general: Can use basic language and formulaic expressions to describe things and answer questions.
specific: Productive: Use basic words or phrases to identify time words.
Interactive: Exchange simple questions and answers about the current day.
learning_outcomes: Can count weather features up to 20, with help (e.g., "Let's count the clouds! One, two, three." "Can you count all the raindrops?").
Can answer simple questions about the weather, using one- or two-word responses (e.g., responding "cold" when asked, "What is the weather today?").
Can express simple feelings or reactions to weather using words and gestures (e.g., saying "I'm hot." while fanning themselves or "I'm cold." with a shivering gesture).

reading.general: Can recognize familiar words in simple texts.
specific: Reading: Identify one-step written directions with visual support.
Reading: Match simple words to corresponding pictures.

learning_outcomes: Can identify weather-related words in simple text instructions (e.g., matching "sun" to a picture of the sun).
Can match simple weather-related words to corresponding pictures (e.g., matching the word "sunny" to a picture of a sunny day).

Can identify sounds of the letters of the alphabet when supported with a concrete item or picture representing that sound in familiar words related to weather (e.g., identifying the sound of the letter /r/ in the word "rainy" when shown a picture of raindrops).

writing.general: Can write about oneself using simple words.
specific: Productive: Fill in a form with their name and age with adult help.
Interactive: Write simple phrases with errors on a drawing or postcard.
learning_outcomes: Can write their name and simple phrases on a weather-related drawing (e.g., labeling a personal drawing of a sunny day with their name and a simple phrase describing the drawing).
Can write simple phrases related to the weather (e.g., "It is sunny.") with support.
Can label pictures of different weather conditions (e.g., drawing a cloud and writing "cloudy").

mediation.general: Can use mediation strategies such as gestures and body language to express basic ideas.
specific: Text: Draw a single picture that represents a simple story or event.
Communication: Use gestures to show how to play a very simple game.
learning_outcomes: Can clarify or confirm understanding of weather by pointing to pictures or using simple words.
Can draw simple pictures representing the weather and label them with help.
Can use gestures or body language to describe weather (e.g., pretending to shiver when it's cold).

Verbs: rain, shine, blow, fall, clear up
Adjectives: sunny, rainy, cloudy, warm, cold, cool, clear, windy
pronunciation_phonemic_awareness: Phonemic awareness: Initial sound of letter /w/ in the word "weather" and identification of sounds of letters of the alphabet in familiar vocabulary (e.g., /r/ in "rainy")

pragmatic: Talking about weather: Describe simple weather conditions (e.g., "It is sunny.") and describe simple reactions to weather (e.g., "I'm cold." or "I'm hot.")
Asking questions about weather: Ask basic questions, such as "What is the weather today?" to learn about daily conditions
sociolinguistic: Weather conversations: Engaging in simple weather-related conversations.

listening.general: Can identify sounds of familiar words and basic phrases spoken slowly and clearly.
specific: Receptive: Identify the topic of a conversation that involves familiar subjects.
Interactive: Respond to simple conversations on familiar topics by using gestures or by pointing.
learning_outcomes: Can show comprehension of age-appropriate numbers when paired with familiar objects (e.g., identifying "three blue flowers" by pointing to the correct group).
Can identify colors and objects when spoken about (e.g., "blue bird" or "red flower").
Can follow simple instructions related to colors and familiar objects by pointing or gesturing (e.g., "Find the blue bird.").

speaking.general: Can use basic language and formulaic expressions to describe things and answer questions.
specific: Productive: Name primary and secondary colors.
Interactive: Express likes or dislikes using simple words and pointing.
learning_outcomes: Can describe objects using colors and simple sentences (e.g., "That's a blue bird.").
Can answer questions about colors and objects, using one or two-word responses (e.g., "What color is it?" "Blue.").
Can express likes and dislikes, using simple words and gestures (e.g., "I like red.").

reading.general: Can recognize familiar words in simple texts.
specific: Reading: Identify pictures that show what happened in a simple story heard.
Reading: Identify simple words for very common symbols.
Phonemic Awareness: Identify sounds of the letters of the alphabet when supported with a concrete item or picture representing that sound.
learning_outcomes: Can listen to a simple story and identify corresponding pictures that illustrate key events (e.g., recognizing the picture of a blue bird mentioned in the story).
Can identify simple words for very common symbols, matching them to images (e.g., linking "flower" with its picture).
Can identify the initial sounds of letters of the alphabet in common objects and things (e.g., /f/ in "fish," /b/ in "bird," and /k/ in "cat").

writing.general: Can write about oneself using simple words.
specific: Productive: Write numbers up to 10 with guidance.
Interactive: Write one-word answers to simple questions.
learning_outcomes: Can write numbers up to ten with teacher guidance to represent objects in drawings (e.g., drawing four flowers and writing "4," drawing five stars, and writing "5.").
Can respond to simple questions about objects or colors by writing one-word answers with teacher support (e.g., "What color is this?" Write "blue." "What is this?" Write "cat.").
Can use simple drawings to communicate about objects and add one-word descriptions (e.g., drawing a green leaf and writing "leaf," drawing a red apple and writing "apple").

mediation.general: Can use mediation strategies such as gestures and body language to express basic ideas.
specific: Text: Identify a few familiar words from a story by connecting them to prior knowledge.
Concept: Use a word and a gesture or drawing to describe a familiar object.
learning_outcomes: Can use simple drawings to communicate about objects (e.g., drawing a blue bird).
Can use gestures or point to objects to clarify their responses when describing colors.

grammatical_features: Present simple (e.g., "It is an orange cat.")

pragmatic: Recognizing colors and objects: Identify familiar objects by color (e.g., "blue bird" or "red flower.")

Counting and identifying colors of objects: Identify and count familiar objects while specifying their color (e.g., "three blue birds" or "two red flowers")

listening.general: Can identify sounds of familiar words and basic phrases spoken slowly and clearly.

Can follow instructions about family-related activities (e.g., "Find a picture of your family.").
Can respond to questions about family members, using gestures or single words (e.g., "Who is he?" "Dad").

speaking.general: Can use basic language and formulaic expressions to describe things and answer questions.
specific: Productive: Locate objects and people, using words.
Interactive: Respond nonverbally to simple yes/no questions by nodding or shaking head.
learning_outcomes: Can identify family members, using simple sentences (e.g., "She is my mom.").
Can answer basic yes/no questions about family members, using nods, gestures, or simple words (e.g., "Is she your mom?").
Can participate in conversations about their family, using one-word responses (e.g., "Who is she?" "Mom.") or two-word responses (e.g., "Who is she?" "My sister.").

reading.general: Can recognize familiar words in simple texts.
specific: Reading: Recognize when written, without visual support, not only their own name but also the names of classmates or family members.
Reading: Point to simple words in the text that identify objects or characters in a picture book.

learning_outcomes: Can recognize family-related words, including own name, in written texts (e.g., "mom," "dad").
Can match names of family members to pictures in books (e.g., matching the word "father" to a picture of a father in a family picture book).

Can identify sounds of the letters of the alphabet when supported with a concrete item or picture representing that sound (e.g., identifying the sound of the letter "S" in the word "sister" when shown a picture of a sister).

writing.general: Can write about oneself using simple words.
specific: Productive: Write their own name and other very familiar words without assistance.

Can draw pictures related to simple sentences they have written about family members (e.g., drawing a picture of "my mom" to accompany the sentence, "This is my mom.").

mediation.general: Can use mediation strategies such as gestures and body language to express basic ideas.
specific: Text: Use pictures or objects to express ideas.

listening.general: Can identify sounds of familiar words and basic phrases spoken slowly and clearly.

Can follow simple instructions related to transportation items as heard in simple stories (e.g., "Find the green car.").
Can respond to simple questions about transportation vehicles by pointing or naming them (e.g., "What color is the car?").

speaking.general: Can use basic language and formulaic expressions to describe things and answer questions.

reading.general: Can recognize familiar words in simple texts.

Verbs: grow, seed, plant, water, bloom, sprout, be (is/are/am)
Adjectives: pink, green, tall, short, small, big, leafy, little
Question word: what
Demonstratives: this, that
Possessive pronouns: my, your, his, her
pronunciation_phonemic_awareness: Phonemic awareness: Identification of sounds of letters of the alphabet in nature-related vocabulary (e.g., /s/ in "sun")

pragmatic: Talking about nature: Describe plants and trees with singular and plural phrases (e.g., "The tree is tall." "The flowers are pink.")
Asking questions in nature: Use basic questions like "What color is the flower?" to learn about plants
sociolinguistic: Respect for nature: Talking about plants and trees using respectful language (e.g., "I like plants.").
